text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column layout with decorated initials and marginal illustrations. Text blocks are aligned vertically with illustrations in the margins.

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold is used prominently for initials and decorative elements. Red and blue are used for textual emphasis and decorative patterns.

features: Marginal illustrations are secondary in importance
Text is organized vertically with a clear hierarchy

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid pen work with gold embellishments
drawing_technique.shading_method: Subtle highlighting with gold and color accents for depth

content_theme.scene_description: The manuscript page for February features a calendar layout with zodiac representation. The month is identified in an ornate gold initial, with accompanying red and blue text entries for feast days. The margin contains a roundel with an illustration possibly representing an activity typical for February, such as a labor of the month. Figures are in detailed attire, seated and engaged in writing. The zodiac symbol of Pisces is present in a separate illustration.

secular: Figures engaged in writing or scholarship, in typical costumes of the period

technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid colors well-preserved, minor abrasions visible
notable_physical_characteristics: Intricate gilding on borders and initials
Delicate brushwork visible in details of marginalia
Consistent ruling with visible plummet lines

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Noble or scholarly patron interested in calendrical and astronomical knowledge

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This manuscript page exemplifies the integration of text and image characteristic of medieval calendars, likely originating from a French scriptorium in the late 13th or early 14th century. The emphasis on the month of February connects to both religious and secular aspects of timekeeping, with decorated initials highlighting liturgical feasts and zodiac symbols indicating an interest in astronomical knowledge. The presence of working and scholarly figures aligns with the educational function of such calendars, which served not only as practical guides for time but also as visual records of the seasons and their associated labors. The careful execution of gold leaf for initials and marginalia reveals the manuscriptâ€™s dual role as a functional object and a display piece, reflecting the wealth and taste of its patron. The script style, Gothic textura quadrata, suggests high professionalism, common in deluxe manuscripts of this period. The choice of colors and detailed marginalia links to broader traditions of Parisian illumination, showing connections to contemporary examples of Books of Hours. Overall, this manuscript showcases the richness of medieval life and learning through its blend of practical, aesthetic, and symbolic content.
